title: Big banks have more female directors than other US industries
text:
Add to myFT Big banks have more female directors than other US industries Financial groups’ lead in danger as proportion grows more slowly than in rest of corporate America Read next How social class can affect your pay Wednesday, 22 February, 2017 Women made up 26% of directors at 21 of the largest banking and capital markets companies by market capitalisation in 2016 by: Shannon Bond in New York 
Big US banks have more female directors than most other big industries but the proportion of women in their boardrooms is growing more slowly than the rest of corporate America, a study has found. 
Women made up 26 per cent of directors at 21 of the largest banking and capital markets companies by market capitalisation in 2016, according to PwC’s Governance Insights Center. That was the same proportion as the boards of 11 big retail companies and more than any of the other seven industry groups PwC studied. Across the entire S&P 500, 21 per cent of board members were female. 
Banking companies may not retain their lead, however, as the industry added new female directors at a slower rate than most others last year. Thirteen per cent of their board hires were women, compared with 32 per cent in the S&P 500. At retailers, 44 per cent of new directors were female. Entertainment and media companies led the pack with women making up 60 per cent of new directors. Insurance companies ranked last at 7 per cent. 
Shareholders have been pressuring companies to refresh their boards with more diverse directors to better respond to new business challenges and to bring them more in line with international norms. 
“Investors want to make sure the board is composed of the right individuals to help the company make the right decisions today and take the company into the future,” said Paula Loop, leader of PwC’s Governance Insights Center. 
It noted that the diversity companies need extends beyond gender to “race, ethnicity, skills, experience, expertise, age and even geography”, but said that gender composition “is a good indicator” of how companies are trying to increase overall diversity. 
PwC’s report did not identify specific companies within the industry groups it examined. According to Financial Times research, among the six biggest US banks by revenue, Wells Fargo has the highest proportion of female board members at 36 per cent, followed by Citigroup at 35 per cent, Bank of America with 31 per cent, Goldman Sachs at 23 per cent, JPMorgan on 17 per cent and Morgan Stanley at 13 per cent. 
Despite a relatively strong presence of women in the boardroom, there are just a handful in top executive positions at the big banks. 
Among the most prominent are Marianne Lake, chief financial officer at JPMorgan Chase, and Mary Erdoes, who runs JPM’s asset management business, both of whom are considered possible successors to Jamie Dimon as chief executive. At Bank of America, Anne Finucane serves as vice-chairman. There are only two female chief executives of banks in the S&P 500: KeyCorp’s Beth Mooney and Margaret Keane of Synchrony Financial. 
The report also tracked whether boards employ mandatory retirement ages and term limits, tools that can help ensure that directors are regularly refreshed. 
“You need to have turnover. If you have a refreshed board, you have an opportunity at least to put on a diverse board member,” Ms Loop said. Read more Review says biggest public companies should disclose number of female executives Thursday, 23 February, 2017 
Banks were less likely than the broader set of S&P 500 companies to set a mandatory retirement age and none in the group studied set term limits for directors. 
Sixty-two per cent of banks set a mandatory retirement age, compared with 73 per cent of the S&P 500. 
Mandatory retirement was most common at retailers, where 91 per cent set a retirement age. This was followed by utilities groups, with 80 per cent, and industrial products, at 78 per cent. 
Only 4 per cent of S&P 500 companies imposed term limits on directors. In four industry groups — banking and capital markets, communications, insurance and technology — no companies have term limits. Limits were most common at retailers, with 18 per cent using them, and entertainment and media companies, with 12 per cent. 
The US continues to lag the UK and Europe in overall boardroom gender diversity. According to recent research from headhunter Egon Zehnder, in western Europe, 26 per cent of board seats are held by women on average, compared with 20 per cent in the US.
